dlgPart.npc_text: You enter a massive, strangely decorated chamber, but at once step back, dizzied, from an abyss. Above, the rock ceiling is hewn with arcane symbols, while at your feet is a vast open space, a bottomless night sky of alien stars, forming no constellations you recognize. This is uncanny, unnatural, sorcery beyond your imagination. You shrink from it instinctively, as if pushed by an invisible hand against the reassuring firmness of the stone wall.

This failure creates a physical anomaly which occupies the same space in two different dimensions at the same time.
The hill on which castle Ganezzar was built was supposedly erected from the plain for defensives purposes, though it would seem much easier and cheaper to simply choose an existing hill. dlgPart.npc_text: Ever so slowly, you ease yourself onto the seat, expecting – dreading – what might happen. The chair is hard and uncomfortable but, except for your palms tingling on the armrests, seems ordinary. A moment later there comes a sound like approaching voices, but it quickly fades away as if breaking against an invisible barrier. The voices are gone, all except one.

“Darius... he had much promise,” says a voice in your head. The voice rings like a bell in the back of your mind, each word sending painful vibrations throughout your body.
“He was strong and eager, yet even with an army at his back he failed to enter Ganezzar. Failed to reach this chamber. Failed to serve me.” The strident voice is in fact your own, your aching jaw opening and closing as your mouth channels the thoughts of the outside entity.
There is a warrior standing in front of an army. Despite having never seen him before, you know who he is, and you feel his eagerness to serve you. His desire to take Ganezzar radiates from him, need that is driving him mad. Then he is lying dead in his tent, fires burning unchecked nearby, his army broken and scattered. You are enraged at the man. He has failed you.
The voice returns. “You are weak,” it says, “feebleminded, alone. Yet here you are.”

“Athazor’s will is strong.” The words ring in your mind, the vibrations seeming to bounce from the inside of your skull. After a moment of silence, a terrifying vision rears before you, a humongous being resembling an octopus or jellyfish – a dome-like head with a multitude of constantly shifting, probing appendages. Where these tentacles trail, reality alters in their wake. Is this the entity the Magi called Athazor?
“I can sense Athazor’s gift in you, protecting your feeble brain. Without it, my attempt to connect our minds would drive you mad.” The strident voice is in fact your own, your aching jaw opening and closing as your mouth channels the thoughts of the outside entity.
Mercifully, the creature fades from view and the perspective changes. You are looking down at a brighter square in the darkness of the void – the room you’re in now. As if riffling through the pages of a thick tome, you see a series of people sitting in that selfsame chair, all reaching out to the entity, each of them killed outright or driven to gibbering insanity. When the last of these have been destroyed you see yourself, and understand that you are as an insect, too small, usually, even to be noticed, too low to be contemptible.
“You are weak,” the voice says, “feebleminded, alone. Yet here you are.”

“In the olden days my disciples drank a special draught before the communion.” The words ring in your mind, the vibrations seeming to bounce from the inside of your skull. After a moment of silence, a vision rears before you. Kneeling men taking turns drinking from a cup, waiting for their God to speak to them.
“I can sense the drug in you, protecting your feeble brain. Without it, my attempt to connect our minds would drive you mad.” The strident voice is in fact your own, your aching jaw opening and closing as your mouth channels the thoughts of the outside entity.
The vision fades from view and the perspective changes. You are looking down at a brighter square in the darkness of the void – the room you’re in now. As if riffling through the pages of a thick tome, you see a series of people sitting in that selfsame chair, all reaching out to the entity, each of them killed outright or driven to gibbering insanity. When the last of these have been destroyed you see yourself, and understand that you are as an insect, too small, usually, even to be noticed, too low to be contemptible.
“You are weak,” the voice says, “feebleminded, alone. Yet here you are.”

“My kind does not define itself in the bleating sounds of lesser beings. Your kind called us the Yazatas – worthy of worship.” A huge square of people kneeling, heads touching the ground. “From a long dead language they named me Balzaar. Bal meant to cross over. Zaar meant vessel. Thus, the one who crossed over and was poured into a vessel, a crude attempt to describe a god.”

dlgAnsw.text: “A god? Is that what you call yourself?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “A communication device. In ages past my generals wore such helmets to war, their armies extensions of my will. My aspect walked your plane in those days and spoke directly with those who wore the amplifiers. Separated as we are now, I can be heard clearly only when the other is in the center of the tear.”

dlgAnsw.text: “A god? Is that what you call yourself?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “It is your word, human. The concept is imprecise, but it describes my kind far better than you can imagine.”
“We know neither beginning nor end. We exist because we wish to exist. We do not struggle for every breath for we draw none.”

dlgAnsw.text: “If you are so mighty, what do you want with us?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Your kind has awakened us. Enticed us with false promises. Tried to enslave us.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Was it you I spoke to earlier?” Describe the circumstances.
“What can you tell me about the one we named Thor-Agoth?”
“What do you want me to do?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “It was one of my brothers, he who favors things that are dead.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What can you tell me about the one we named Thor-Agoth?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Thor-Agoth,” the voice says slowly, as if remembering something long forgotten. “He was almost human in his foolishness, and found himself imprisoned in a mortal body for centuries, buried in the tomb his acolytes built.”
You see a sprawling temple complex with a ziggurat rising in the center.

dlgAnsw.text: “What do you want me to do?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “It is the only way.” A flood of confused images follows, an anchor, a naked man laid out for surgery, a human brain exposed to a glaring blue light, his freshly scarred body convulsing, and finally, at the apex of a pyramid, an unnatural light pouring upwards into the heavens.

dlgAnsw.text: “What can you tell me about the one we named Thor-Agoth?”
“What do you want me to do?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Serve me. Bring Meru to Al-Akia. Complete the ritual.”
You see a large pyramid, an unnatural light pouring upwards into the heavens, as the voice recites a complex mantra, burning each step into your mind.

You are standing atop a high structure, and everywhere you turn your gaze impossible distances are revealed. The empire is laid out at your feet, and it crawls with pale, puny things, bowing and scraping, creatures which fear and serve you. The creatures are men. They are what you used to be.
